timeline.title: A Brief History of American Journalism
timeline.subtitle: 1690 - Present Day
timeline.event:
The first American newspaper ended in the arrest of the publisher in 1690.

Public Domain

Benjamin Franklin circulated the most popular newspaper in the colonies in 1729.

Public Domain

event.title: Declaration of Independence & the First Amendment

timeline.event:
In 1776, a Boston newspaper ran a story about the first battle of the American Revolution.

Public Domain

event.title: Declaration of Independence & the First Amendment

timeline.event:
The same year, several newspapers ran the complete Declaration of Independence, sharing the document with the colonies.

Public Domain

In the early 1800s, many more daily newspapers and regular magazines came out, including some in other languages.

Public Domain

By 1835, newspaper sections focusing on sports and other features appeared. Shortly after, Horace Greeley became an influential news editor with the New York Tribune.

Public Domain

By 1835, newspaper sections focusing on sports and other features appeared. Shortly after, Horace Greeley became an influential news editor with the New York Tribune.

Public Domain

The New York Times, still one of the most popular newspapers today, was founded in 1851.

Public Domain

In the mid- to late 1800s, telegraphs and railroads helped reporters send news across long distances. Photographers and reporters traveled to cover the Civil War.

Public Domain

William Randolph Hearst began his career as a newspaper mogul in 1887.

Public Domain

Publisher Joseph Pulitzer died in 1911, leaving funds to Columbia University to open a graduate school of journalism. He also left money to establish the Pulitzer Prize, which is still considered one of the highest awards a journalist can receive.

Public Domain

It wasn’t until the 1920s that radio entered the scene, giving audiences a new option for gathering their news.

© 2010 AP Images

Filmmaker and actor Orson Welles released a fictional exposé of the newspaper industry with his 1941 movie Citizen Kane. It depicted a negative characterization of William Randolph Hearst as the wealthy publisher, Kane.

© 1941 RKO/Turner Entertainment

The same decade, television news started, and films began showing short clips of news items before or after the shows.

© 2010 AP Images

In the 1970s, newspapers, radio, and television covered the Vietnam War. Bob Woodward and Carl Bernstein of the Washington Post met with an anonymous source, known to the public only as “Deep Throat,” to uncover the Nixon Watergate scandal.

© 2010 Simon & Schuster

Rupert Murdoch began to build his media empire in 1973.

Public Domain

By the 1980s, many news organizations had moved from typewriters to computers.

© 2010 AP Images
With the introduction of the Internet, news sources found other avenues to deliver information to the public. Citizen journalism also began to rise in popularity.
